thread.title: Storm Doris: Forecasters warn of 80mph winds and snow to batter the country - but is your area affected?
thread.title_full: Storm Doris: Forecasters warn of 80mph winds and snow to batter the country - but is your area affected?

author: Keyan Milanian
title: Storm Doris: Forecasters warn of 80mph winds and snow to batter the country - but is your area affected?
text:
Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The Met Office has warned that Storm Doris will bring 'damaging winds', rain and snow to the UK and could cause chaos on transport networks. 
An amber National Severe Weather Warning - in place until this evening - has been issued with winds expected to reach up to 80mph across large parts of the UK. 
And, since being expanded southwards, the amber warning covers around 50% of the country and is in force from 6am to 8pm today. 
This morning, an 87mph gust was recorded on the Galway coast in the Republic of Ireland. 
Chief Met Office Meteorologist Eddy Carroll said: “Storm Doris will bring damaging winds with some significant disruption likely to central parts of the UK on Thursday, whilst southern Scotland will see some heavy snowfall. Read More Storm Doris: Tree crashes onto car with boy inside as gale force winds batter UK 
"People in the warning areas should be prepared for disruptive stormy weather, wind speeds in some locations could reach up to 80 mph so make sure you keep up to date with your local forecast and any weather warnings for your area.” 
It is likely there will be snow on high ground in the far north of England and for much of Scotland which could fall to low levels in some of these areas. Storm Doris to bring 80mph winds with severe weather warnings issued for much of the country (Photo: MetOffice/Twitter) Scotland 
Storm Doris will bring strong winds, snow, wintry showers and freezing low temperatures to many parts of Scotland. 
With an Amber weather warning for snow issued for the south of Scotland, including the areas in and around Glasgow and Edinburgh, there may be more than 20cm in places. 
Heavy showers are set to hit with temperatures dropping to as a low as -4C in some areas. The UK will be battered by 80mph winds (Photo: PA) North West 
The area will see heavy rain, hill snow and coastal gales this morning. 
While the rain will ease in the afternoon it will turn cold with sunny spells and wintry showers. 
Wintry showers and -2C lows are expected with a risk of icy patches. Read More Midlands 
Heavy and blustery rain will be likely with possible gales in some parts of the region. 
While temperatures could be as high as 8C they are expected to also drop to freezing at times today. 
The Met Office have warned locals to expect wintry showers and icy patches but said there will also be clear spells possible. Storm Barney approaches South West 
The worst of the weather and heaviest rain is expected first thing this morning but gales are likely all day. 
Gusts of up to 50mph are likely in the towns and valleys, and 60mph on coasts and hills. 
Frosts in the region are unlikely with the maximum temperature reaching about 11C although the Met Office have warned tonight - while dry and clearing - will be cooler than recent nights. (Photo: MetOffice/Twitter) South East and London 
A damp morning, with a band of heavy blustery rain spreading east. 
It will then turn very windy with gales, perhaps turning severe along coasts, leading to the risk of disruption. 
Some brighter spells are possible, but also further outbreaks of rain with a brisk wind to gradually ease overnight. Students brave high winds and rain on Blackpool promenade as Britain prepares for high winds over the next two days on October 20, 2014 in Blackpool, England. (Photo: Getty Images) Northern Ireland 
Some rain and hill snow which may be heavy along the north coasts. 
While it will clear towards midday scattered heavy showers will follow. 
The southern counties will be clearest although it will remain cold with patchy frost. Waves whipped up by high winds hit Blackpool's sea wall as Britain's first ever named storm, Storm Abigail, hits the North West (Photo: getty) Wales 
The Met Office expects severe gales to blow across Wales with gusts as strong as 80mph on coasts and hills as well as showers. 
Fallen trees and power line damage is 'likely' with winds easing towards tonight. 
The weather will clear tonight with a few showers and snow continuing to fall on hills while ice may form on a few higher-level country roads. Like us on Facebook
